title: Photosynthesis for Inclusive 5th Grade
description: A fully adapted 45-minute lesson plan on photosynthesis for a class with ASD, ADHD, Dyslexia, and Hearing Impairment students. Demonstrates AiLine's multi-accessibility planning with curriculum alignment, differentiated activities, and export variants.
subject: Science
prompt: Create a 45-minute lesson plan on photosynthesis for 5th graders. The class includes students with autism (needs visual schedules and predictable routines), ADHD (needs chunked activities with movement breaks), dyslexia (needs large print and bionic reading), and hearing impairment (needs captions and sign language support). Align to NGSS standards and include differentiated activities for approaching, on-level, and advanced learners.

cached_plan.title: Photosynthesis: How Plants Make Their Own Food
cached_plan.subject: Science

objectives.text: Support an argument that plants get the materials they need for growth chiefly from air and water.
Use models to describe that energy in animals' food was once energy from the sun.
Draw on information from multiple print or digital sources, demonstrating the ability to locate an answer to a question quickly.

cross_cutting_concepts: Energy and Matter: Matter is transported into, out of, and within systems.
Systems and System Models: A system can be described in terms of its components and their interactions.
disciplinary_core_ideas: LS1.C: Organization for Matter and Energy Flow in Organisms -- Plants acquire their material for growth chiefly from air and water.

steps.title: Hook: The Mystery of the Growing Plant
instructions: Display two photos side-by-side on the projector: a small seed and a tall sunflower.
Ask the class: 'This sunflower weighs 8 pounds. The seed weighed almost nothing. Where did all that weight come from?'
Activate closed-caption mode on the projector for Sofia (hearing impairment).
Display the question in large print on a second screen or printed card for Lucas (dyslexia).
Allow 60 seconds of think time before accepting responses.
Record student hypotheses on a visible anchor chart using simple drawings alongside text.
activities: Think-Pair-Share: Students whisper their hypothesis to a shoulder partner before sharing with the class.
assessment: Observe: Are students connecting plant growth to an external source (sun, water, soil)?
Note misconceptions on the anchor chart with a question mark for revisiting later.

steps.title: Direct Instruction: The Photosynthesis Equation
instructions: Transition cue: Ring the chime twice (consistent signal for Alex's routine).
Display the visual equation diagram: Sun + Water + CO2 --> Glucose + Oxygen.
Use color-coded arrows: yellow (sunlight), blue (water), green (CO2), orange (glucose), white (oxygen).
Walk through each input and output using the diagram, pointing to each element.
Pause after each component for a 'thumbs up / thumbs sideways' comprehension check.
For Sofia: ensure the ASL interpreter is positioned next to the screen; provide a printed diagram with labels.
For Lucas: distribute the large-print version (18pt OpenDyslexic font) of the diagram.
For Maya: announce 'We have 10 minutes for this part, then we move and do something hands-on!'
activities: Students label a blank photosynthesis diagram at their desks while the teacher explains.
Color-coding activity: Students use the same colors (yellow, blue, green, orange, white) to fill in their diagram.
assessment: Thumbs up/sideways check after each component (sun, water, CO2, glucose, O2).
Walk the room to check that diagrams are labeled correctly.

steps.title: Movement Break
instructions: Transition cue: Ring the chime once.
Lead the class in 'Photosynthesis Stretches': arms up like a tree reaching for the sun, wiggle fingers like leaves, stomp feet like roots drinking water.
This movement break is essential for Maya (ADHD) and beneficial for all learners.
Use a visual timer displayed on the screen so Alex (ASD) can see exactly when the break ends.
activities: Whole-class guided movement: 'Reach for the sun! Wiggle your leaves! Stomp your roots!'
assessment: No formal assessment -- this is a regulation and re-engagement break.

steps.title: Hands-On Investigation: Leaf Lab
instructions: Transition cue: Display the visual schedule step showing 'Lab Time' with a clock icon.
Distribute materials: real leaves, magnifying glasses, flashlights, and observation worksheets.
Station 1 (approaching): Guided observation -- use a pre-filled worksheet with sentence starters ('I see ___ on the leaf. The leaf feels ___.').
Station 2 (on-level): Compare two different leaves. Record observations in a T-chart. Hypothesize why they differ.
Station 3 (advanced): Design a simple experiment. Predict what happens if you cover half a leaf with foil for 3 days. Write a hypothesis using 'If... then... because...'
Groups rotate through stations (5 minutes each), or stay at their assigned tier.
For Alex (ASD): Provide a step-by-step visual checklist for the lab, laminated and wipeable.
For Maya (ADHD): Set a visible 5-minute timer per station; offer the option to stand at a tall table.
For Lucas (dyslexia): Worksheets printed in 16pt OpenDyslexic font; oral response option available.
For Sofia (hearing): Written instructions at each station; visual cue cards for group communication.
activities: Station rotation: Students explore leaves at their differentiation tier.
Draw and label leaf parts (cuticle, stomata, veins) on their observation sheet.
Use magnifying glasses to find stomata on the underside of the leaf.
assessment: Circulate and ask probing questions: 'Where does the CO2 enter the leaf?' (stomata).
Check observation worksheets for accuracy of leaf part labels.
Listen for scientific vocabulary usage during station discussions.

steps.title: Synthesis: Revisiting Our Hypotheses
instructions: Transition cue: Ring the chime twice (return to whole group).
Return to the anchor chart from the hook.
Ask: 'Now that we have learned about photosynthesis, can we answer our mystery? Where did the sunflower's weight come from?'
Guide students to understand: most of the mass comes from CO2 in the air (converted to glucose), not from the soil.
Cross out or revise incorrect hypotheses with student permission.
Add the correct explanation using student-friendly language and the visual equation.
activities: Whole-class discussion revisiting the anchor chart.
Students write or draw one thing they learned on a sticky note and place it on the 'I Learned' board.
assessment: Listen for students correcting their own misconceptions (self-regulation).
Sticky notes: check for accurate understanding of photosynthesis inputs and outputs.

steps.title: Exit Ticket & Closure
instructions: Distribute exit tickets (differentiated format options).
Option A (written): 'Explain photosynthesis in 2-3 sentences using the words: sunlight, water, carbon dioxide, glucose, oxygen.'
Option B (drawing): 'Draw the photosynthesis process with labeled arrows.'
Option C (oral): 'Tell your teacher or a partner what photosynthesis is.' (Record with voice memo app.)
Option D (multiple choice): 3-question MC quiz with large print and visual supports.
For Alex: provide the written prompt on his visual schedule as the last step of the day.
For Sofia: accept exit ticket in written form or via the captioned video response option.
Collect exit tickets. Preview tomorrow's lesson: 'Tomorrow we will test what happens to a plant without sunlight!'
activities: Students complete their chosen exit ticket format independently.
assessment: Exit ticket analysis: Sort into 'Got it', 'Almost', 'Needs reteaching' piles.
Target: 80% of students demonstrate understanding of the basic photosynthesis equation.

summary: Today we learn how plants make their own food using sunlight, water, and air.
We will look at real leaves with magnifying glasses.
You can show what you learned by writing, drawing, or talking.

steps.title: The Mystery
instructions: Look at the two pictures of the seed and the sunflower.
Think: Where did all that weight come from?
Share your idea with a partner.
check_for_understanding: Can you guess where the plant's weight came from?
self_regulation_prompts: It is okay if your guess changes later. Scientists update their ideas too!

steps.title: Learning the Equation
instructions: Watch the diagram on the screen.
Color your own diagram using the matching colors.
Yellow = sunlight, Blue = water, Green = CO2, Orange = sugar, White = oxygen.
check_for_understanding: Can you name the 3 things a plant needs to make food?
self_regulation_prompts: If you feel stuck, look at the color-coded diagram on the board.

steps.title: Stretch Break
instructions: Stand up! Reach for the sun!
Wiggle your fingers like leaves!
Stomp your feet like roots drinking water!
self_regulation_prompts: Take a deep breath. We are getting ready for lab time next.

steps.title: Leaf Lab
instructions: Pick up your leaf and magnifying glass.
Look closely at the leaf. What do you see?
Draw what you see on your worksheet.
Find the tiny holes (stomata) on the back of the leaf.
check_for_understanding: Where does CO2 enter the leaf?
self_regulation_prompts: If your group is too loud, you can move to the quiet corner to finish your observations.

steps.title: What Did We Learn?
instructions: Look at our chart from the beginning.
Did your guess change?
Write or draw one thing you learned on a sticky note.
check_for_understanding: Where does most of the sunflower's weight come from?
self_regulation_prompts: It is great if you changed your mind! That means you learned something new.

steps.title: Show What You Know
instructions: Pick how you want to show your learning: write, draw, talk, or multiple choice.
Complete your exit ticket.
Turn it in to the teacher.
check_for_understanding: Can you explain photosynthesis in your own words?
self_regulation_prompts: You do not need to rush. Pick the option that works best for you.

glossary: Photosynthesis -- the process plants use to make food from sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide
Chloroplast -- the tiny part inside a leaf cell where photosynthesis happens (like a food factory)
Carbon dioxide (CO2) -- a gas in the air that plants breathe in through their leaves
Glucose -- the sugar (food) that plants make during photosynthesis
Oxygen (O2) -- the gas that plants release into the air (what we breathe)
Stomata -- tiny holes on the bottom of a leaf where gases go in and out
Sunlight -- the energy from the sun that powers photosynthesis
alternative_response_options: Record a voice memo explaining your answer
Use sign language to explain to an interpreter

strategies: Visual schedule displayed at the front of the room with each lesson phase clearly marked
Consistent transition cues: chime rings twice for whole-group, once for breaks
Step-by-step laminated lab checklist with checkboxes
Advance notice of transitions: '2 minutes until we switch activities'
Predictable lesson structure: Hook, Learn, Move, Explore, Discuss, Show
Quiet corner available during lab for sensory regulation
do_not: Do not change the order of activities without advance notice
Do not use sudden loud sounds or unexpected changes in lighting
Do not require spontaneous verbal responses without processing time
notes: Alex responds best to visual metaphors and step-by-step sequences
Allow extra processing time (minimum 5 seconds) before expecting a response

strategies: Activities chunked into 5-15 minute segments with clear start/end signals
Movement break built into the lesson at the midpoint
Visible countdown timer displayed on screen during each activity
Option to stand at a tall table during lab work
Hands-on materials (real leaves, magnifying glasses) to maintain engagement
Fidget-friendly seating option available during direct instruction
do_not: Do not assign more than 15 minutes of seated work without a movement opportunity
Do not rely solely on auditory instruction for key concepts
Do not penalize for movement during transitions
notes: Maya benefits from advance time warnings: '5 minutes left at this station'
Pair Maya with a focused partner during station work for mutual support

strategies: All printed materials in 16pt minimum using OpenDyslexic font
Bionic reading mode available for digital text (bold first syllable of each word)
Color-coded diagram reduces reliance on text-only information
Oral response option for exit ticket (voice memo recording)
Sentence starters provided on worksheets: 'I observed...', 'This means...'
Audio version of all written instructions available via QR code
do_not: Do not require timed reading of lengthy passages
Do not penalize spelling or handwriting on content assessments
Do not use serif fonts or small print on any materials
notes: Lucas has strong verbal skills -- leverage oral explanations as assessment evidence
Pre-teach key vocabulary (photosynthesis, chloroplast, stomata) before the lesson

strategies: ASL interpreter positioned adjacent to the projection screen at all times
Closed captions enabled on all projected video and audio content
Written instructions posted at each lab station (not just verbal)
Visual cue cards for group work communication (thumbs up, question mark, check mark)
Teacher faces Sofia when speaking and avoids covering mouth
Printed copy of all spoken explanations available on Sofia's desk
do_not: Do not speak while facing the whiteboard with back to students
Do not rely on auditory-only signals for transitions (pair chime with visual flash)
Do not assume lip-reading is sufficient for complex scientific vocabulary
notes: Sofia excels with visual diagrams -- the color-coded photosynthesis equation is ideal
Pair chime transition cues with a visual signal (flashing classroom light or raising a colored card)

strategies: Multiple means of representation: visual diagram, verbal explanation, hands-on exploration
Multiple means of expression: write, draw, speak, or select from choices
Multiple means of engagement: mystery hook, movement break, lab investigation
Clear learning objectives posted and referenced throughout the lesson
Anchor chart visible throughout for ongoing reference
do_not: Do not assume all students learn best through a single modality
notes: UDL principles embedded throughout -- adaptations benefit all learners, not just those with identified needs

media_requirements: Photosynthesis equation diagram (color-coded, large format) -- needs alt text for screen readers
Seed-to-sunflower comparison photos -- needs descriptive alt text
Movement break instructional video -- needs closed captions and ASL overlay
Lab observation worksheet -- needs large-print variant (16pt OpenDyslexic) and audio description
Exit ticket templates -- available in standard, large-print, and screen-reader-compatible formats
ui_recommendations: Low-distraction mode: hide sidebar navigation during lesson delivery
Large-print toggle: increase all text to 18pt minimum with extra line spacing
High-contrast mode: dark background, bright text for visual clarity
Bionic reading mode: bold first syllable for dyslexia support
Visual schedule panel: persistent sidebar showing current step and time remaining
teacher_review_points: Verify ASL interpreter availability for the lesson period
Confirm large-print materials are ready for Lucas (16pt OpenDyslexic)
Test the closed-caption system on the classroom projector before class
Prepare the quiet corner with noise-reducing headphones for Alex
Set up the standing table option for Maya before students arrive
human_review_reasons: ASL interpretation quality should be verified by a certified interpreter
Lab safety protocols should be reviewed for students with sensory sensitivities
Exit ticket difficulty calibration should be checked against actual student reading levels

materials_needed: Color-coded photosynthesis equation poster (large format, laminated)
Fresh leaves (2-3 varieties: maple, oak, spinach)
Colored pencils/crayons (yellow, blue, green, orange, white sets)
Visual schedule cards (laminated, with Velcro backing)
Chime or bell for transition signals
Noise-reducing headphones (2 pairs, available in quiet corner)
Exit ticket templates (4 formats: written, drawing, MC, oral recording)

approaching.description: Students who need additional scaffolding to access grade-level content
modifications: Pre-filled observation worksheet with sentence starters and word banks
Guided small-group instruction during lab time with teacher or aide
Simplified photosynthesis equation: 'Sun + Water + Air = Plant Food + Oxygen'
Multiple-choice exit ticket with visual supports
Standard observation worksheet with guiding questions
Partner work during lab with structured discussion prompts
Full photosynthesis equation with chemical formulas introduced
Written or drawn exit ticket with choice

advanced.description: Students ready for deeper exploration and extension
modifications: Design an experiment: 'What happens if we block sunlight from half a leaf?'
Write a hypothesis using If/Then/Because structure
Research connection: How does photosynthesis relate to the food chain?
Open-ended exit ticket: 'Explain why photosynthesis matters for all living things on Earth'

standards_aligned.description: Plants get materials for growth chiefly from air and water
Energy in food was once energy from the sun
Draw on information from multiple sources

accessibility_adaptations: Chunked activities with movement break for ADHD
ASL interpreter + closed captions for Hearing Impairment
UDL multi-modal engagement for all learners
scorecard.router_rationale: High complexity lesson plan with multi-accessibility requirements. Selected Sonnet for balanced quality and structured output. Token estimate: ~2,400 input, ~4,800 output. Structured output weight: 0.9.
scorecard.time_saved_estimate: Approximately 3.5 hours of manual lesson planning, differentiation design, and accessibility adaptation work compressed into 8 seconds of AI pipeline execution.
